segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorn at University of California, Berkeley, interviewing Peter Boyce.
And let's start at the beginning.
Peter, what's your full name?
It's Peter Bradford Boyce.
And when and where were you born?
Born in New York City on November 30th, 1936.
How did you first get interested in astronomy?
I took a course from Bart Bach at Harvard.
What were you majoring in then?
I was going to be pre-med.
And one course in astronomy, and it was all over.
Actually, I was prepared for it because my father, we lived in the country, moved out of New York City at the age of one and a half, one of the best decisions in my life, I think.
And moved to the country, and my father was very interested in the seasons.
We did farming and the change of the sun and the return of the sun.
that allowed us to start planning again was really important to my father, who was a novelist by trade.
And so we used to go out and look at the northern lights and the constellations
appearance of a dog star showed that winter was coming along.
And so we always were interested in the sky.
And when I was in high school, I went to the school whose football coach was the father of Walter Orr Roberts.
And Walter Roberts came in and gave a couple of lectures in the school.
And of course, the kind of thing he was doing at the high altitude observatory and making time lapse movies of the
solar prominence is really exciting to a young kid.
And I got interested enough to want to build my own telescope, which I did in high school.
But I wasn't thinking of that as a career.
I'm not even sure I knew that astronomy was a viable career at that time.
And I went to Harvard, really set to major in pre-med because I wanted to be a doctor.
had a semester course to spare in chemistry, because I took the full year of chemistry in half a year as an advanced course.
And I had a year of science to spare and took an astronomy course, and that was it.
Did you switch majors?
Well, I don't think we had to really declare a major in the freshman year, but I'm sure after that, I immediately declared as a sophomore

be an astronomy major, and we had 11 other astronomy undergraduate majors that year, and they set up a whole series of courses designed to accommodate both the astronomy major students and the beginning graduate students.
So we had a mixture of courses that were absolutely fantastic as a preparation for further work in astronomy.
What year did you get your bachelor's degree?
Then where did you go to graduate school?
I went to grad school in Michigan.
Married a woman who was a year behind me, and she accelerated, and I waited six months.
So I got to Michigan in January of 59.
And when I came to Michigan, it was a time of great change.
And they came to Michigan to study under the faculty of Aller, Liller, Miller, Mueller, Moeller, and Goldberg.
And by the time I left, all of them had departed the scene except Freeman Miller.
Yeah, that was described as a supernova explosion.
Yeah, something like that.
The legislature wouldn't give them a big telescope.
That's right, yeah.
So I got my doctorate in 63.
Okay, who was your thesis advisor and what did you do?
I worked on the Orion Nebula, used Bob Tull's scanner that he built for his thesis, photoelectric spectrum scanner, single channel, and observed the hydrogen bomber decrement in the Orion Nebula.
And by comparing the strengths of the lines with the theoretical calculations, I was able to show that
There was a lot of dust in the nebula or in front of the nebula.
It was central with the nebula, however.
I forgot to mention the date.
This is June 7, 1993.
Okay, you got your PhD, and then presumably you got a job.
I got a job at Lowell Observatory.
How did you get that kind of job?

Well, John Hall had done some polarization studies in the Orion Nebula, and I found an AAS abstract of it and no other reference to it, so I called him and wrote him and asked for further data, and he sent me some data and said it was never published, though.
But it, again, was sort of confirmatory that there was a lot of dust involved in the nebular complex.
So I said I was getting out soon, and also just because of that, I asked him if there were any jobs around Lowell and got a letter back inviting me to come and interview.
So Bill Sinton had gotten...
NSF grant, I guess, and had money to hire somebody.
When did you arrive at Moab?
1963 in September.
That September, about a week after I arrived, we had an observing run with the interferometer.
I knew nothing about interferometry.
It was an interferometric spectrometer.
a root keel prism interferometer in the 2 micron range.
And we had 10 clear days, 10 clear nights, actually.
And what telescope?
Well, at that time, it was the 69-inch telescope at Anderson Mesa at Lowell.
And it was the original Ohio State, Ohio Wesleyan telescope.
And so we worked our butts off.
And I thought, boy, this is quite different from my thesis in Michigan, where I actually went to a New Year's Eve party one clear night instead of going out to the telescope.
And it was March before I could get back on the telescope again because of the weather.
So I thought I was in heaven.
Of course, that's the same thing as the Brouwer fortnight.
I never got 10 clear nights in a row again on my whole 10 years at Lowell.
It was an exciting time.
What objects were you observing?
We were observing cool stars, long period variable stars.

And one of the, the only place we published it was in Stein Telescope, but we did detect water, the water bands in Tri-Signe and showed that they went away at maximum light and were strongly there at minimum light.
Global, of course, is most famous for planetary work, but they always did, from the very beginning, do stellar and galactic work.
Well, that's right.
Bill was doing a lot of planetary work originally, and I think he kind of got discouraged, I guess, when he had this false positive detection of the C-H band on Mars.
And so he was...
doing stellar astronomy at that time.
But he liked to do the instruments.
He liked to fiddle with them and make them work.
And building on Larry Mertz's interferometry experience where Larry and Bill Sinton crossed paths at Harvard while I was an undergraduate there, actually,
And Bill had built this interferometer, and it was really working very well.
I mean, we got some nice spectra for the time.
Of course, these days, what we would spend all night on, they can do in 10 minutes.
When you started at Lowell, who was on the staff there?
Do you remember?
Well, John Hall was the director.
E.C.
Slipher was still alive, buried in the midst of his cigar box filing system of all the plates of Mars that they had ever taken at various Lowell-funded telescopes.
Bill Sinton was there.
Bill Tift was there.
I was trying to remember who was there when we first came.
Some of the exciting people.
I think when I showed up that year, Karl Rakos from Austria was there for the first time.
Wojtek Cieminski had been there and gone.
I don't remember who else right now was on the staff at the beginning.
When you got there, was there much planetary work being done?
There wasn't a lot of planetary work at that time.
The Slifers were taking some pictures, but there was a lot of preparation, I think, for the coming Planetary Center and excitement.
I guess the big thing that was going on was the ACIC project, the Lunar Mapping Project, and the Aeronautical Chart and Information Center.
There were as many people doing that as we had people on the Lowell staff.
And they tied up the 24-inch telescope most of the time, doing a lot of visual filling in of details on the map.
When you went there, did you feel that real astronomers looked down on people that worked at Lowell Territory?
Well, I was too naive to know whether
to consider that.
I was just charged up to be going to a place that had such a name.
I was fairly well treated, I must say.
And every paper that I was given, I'd given at meetings and so forth.
It was received pretty well.
I didn't seem to feel too discriminated against.
What I did feel very strongly was that
the old-time planetary astronomers would look down upon, people who would look at either an image.
I mean, E.C.
Slipher would pick an image out.

Now, he obviously was looking through the telescope at the same time, and this colored his vision of what he saw on the photograph, but he would point out things and say, this is low-lying morning haze, and this over here is afternoon cumulus.
when he had no basis for being able to differentiate that kind of thing at all on Mars.
And so I also was very skeptical that this was real science, just having somebody sit there and give their opinions of what they were actually seeing.
What was the attitude of the staff members towards the late Percival Lowell?
Oh, I guess we're pretty grateful that he had founded the observatory.
We're grateful that he sent A.E.

Douglas out looking for a place and grateful of the citizens of Flagstaff who met the train with a brass band and escorted him up Mars Hill or what was to become Mars Hill and grateful that it was clear and rather good observing conditions at the time he was searching for the site.

You know, Lowell had a, I guess we sort of wished that he had not passed away so soon because clearly the observatory was eking along hand to mouth on the endowment, the rather minuscule endowment which the observatory had, and we all felt, I think, that it would have been much bigger
had Lowell survived a little bit longer and the estate hadn't been in such a turmoil and put such a pinch on the observatory during the 30s and 40s.
When you were there, was Lowell still in the string and bailing wire hand-to-mouth existence that it was famous for?
Oh yeah, sure.

I mean, that was very frustrating at times, and you couldn't buy enough screwdrivers to be sure that you always had one at the telescope, although Henry Giklis used to say he was absolutely certain that the top of Anderson Mesa was littered with screwdrivers six inches deep somewhere, because he had bought so many.
You stayed at Lowell for 10 years.
Yes.
And what did you work on?
Well, I started out to work with Bill Sinton and then on the Orion Nebula again.
And then I built a spectrum scanner funded by the observatory itself and started to use that on planetary nebulae.

Then I built, following Carl Rakosh's visit, where he developed what he called an area scanner, which was a way to wipe a slit across the star, a double star in particular, and get a profile of the two components, which you could then deconvolve and get much more accurate photoelectric magnitudes for stars which were normally too close to resolve in conventional photometry.

this was such a powerful technique that i began to use it and put a spectrum i mean a scanning aperture in front of my spectrum scanner at scanning and right angles to the dispersion and i used then the spectrum scanner as a movable square bandpass very well defined bandpass filter and
turn to my love of gaseous nebulae and would scan these planetary nebulae and H-alpha, H-beta, and the oxygen lines and so forth, and look at the structure of the planetary nebulae.
And then one night, Mars was up in the sky, and people were kind of excited because it was an opposition.
And I looked at it.
And of course, it's a gorgeous sight for somebody who'd never paid much attention to planets before.
And I said, well, I'll try to scan it.

Scanning a planetary nebula meant for me, a planetary nebula meant for me being on there for half an hour, 45 minutes, and then building up enough statistics that you would have a reasonably noise-free profile of the distribution of the element you were looking at
across the nebula.
So I did the same thing to Mars, and in 30 seconds, I had the biggest, brightest, most noise-free profile that I'd ever seen in my life.
And so I thought, well, this is maybe something I should do.
And I looked at Mars.
I looked in the red.
I looked in the blue.
And the profiles were so different.
And of course, you can't see any details on the surface in blue.
And you could in red.
And I thought, well, gee, I could measure some of the differences here.
And I began to look at the planetary literature to see what was known and what kind of accurate measurements had been made of the surface photometry of the different areas of the planet.
I found there was nothing, really nothing.
And I said, well, this is fine.
So I started to work on the planets then.
Did you ever get any NASA support for that work, or was it observatory?
If I got, well, John Hall had the peculiar, and as I later found out, absolutely false assumption that if you put in a proposal and it was turned down, you got a black mark in the agency's book.
And so you should never put in a proposal unless you were absolutely sure it was going to be funded.
And he didn't think that my suggestions for proposals would immediately get funded, and so he didn't want me to send them in.
I think that my salary was partly paid by the NASA contract from time to time.
This was after the Planetary Center had been established and Bill Baum had come.
Ten years after you came, had the observatory, had NASA money really changed?
Oh yes, it changed it a lot.
First of all, the Planetary Center gave us a new building, really major facilities for a lot of things and money for instrumentation that was highly welcome.
and made a major impact.
We expanded the staff in the workshops and things like that, but it just made a difference in night and day.
At the same time, Bill Sinton and I
had gotten into using locally available computers first down at the business school at the NAU, which was the first computer in Flagstaff, an old IBM 1620.
And we rewrote the Fourier transform program that Bill was using to produce the spectra from his interferograms to run on the 1620.
And then we...

finally persuaded Lowell that they had to buy an IBM 1130, which was sort of the first reasonably priced computer that a smaller institution could afford to really get that had sufficient capability to be a worthwhile computer.
So we got the 1130, and Bill and I were put in charge of it, and I eventually became sort of the director
the de facto director of the computer center for four years.
After Lowell, where did you go?
After Lowell, I came to NSF as a program director for astronomical instrumentation for supposedly for two years and stayed for six, I guess, 73 to 79.
And then where did you go?

last year or the next to the last year that stay at nsf i got a department of commerce science and technology fellowship and spent a year on capitol hill working for mo udall came back discovered that the nsf as an agency didn't want to know about my experience on the hill didn't want to put it to any use at all and in fact the congressional office at nsf thought that

any suggestions I made were poaching on their territory and so I was really what I had learned was just never put to use at all and I was so disgusted that this kind of thing was going on when I could see that there were things that NSF should do to change its image in Congress and I applied for the job of

executive officer of the AAS, which at that point came open, I sort of applied as a lark and discovered that my ideas of where the society should go and the search committee's ideas were really so congruent as to be a remarkable match.
And they hired me, and that's where I've been ever since.
Well, as the executive director, you have the continuity that the other officers lack.
One thing I want to ask you from your standpoint is the creation of separate sub-societies, such as the original one, which is high energy astrophysics, but then vision for planetary astronomy.
There was a lot of worry that this would split up astronomy and all that sort of stuff.
Do you think that the, well, what do you think about these divisions?
I have mixed emotions.
I think by and large it's a very important thing.
When the planetary division, let me start with the high energy astrophysics division, they have to be members of the parent society in order to be members of the division.
And that has worked out very well.
It's given an impetus to the high energy astrophysics, which I think was
very important at the time the division was started.
Well, weren't those guys threatening to go to the American Geophysical Union?
No, this is the high energy.
Oh, this is high energy.
Then I think the first division, in fact, was the planetary division.
And I think that also was very important because planetary astronomy sort of had three homes.
There were a number of people who were astronomers and belonged to the AAS.
There were a number of people who were atmospheric physicists who belonged to the, well, I suppose the American Meteorological Society.
And then the planetary surface geologists mostly belonged to AGU.
And there was no one place where they could feel at home.
And part of the major rationale for establishing the planetary division was, in fact, to give them a home

where they didn't have to pay too much in the way of dues, so we did have the affiliate membership, division affiliate membership, with very low dues, but it provided an opportunity where they all had a home and you could meet and have all these people attend the meeting without having to pay the much higher dues of the parent society.
And I think that's a very important function, and I think it's been very, very healthy for the
planetary field as a whole.
People always make comments like, well, it's too bad that they're diverging and everything.
But I just wonder in the good old days, for example, did Alistair pay any attention whatsoever to planetary studies?
Oh, no.
There was no.
That was getting back to one of our earlier questions.
That was a really important thing to highlight the fact that, in fact,
people were doing what I was doing and trying to bring some kind of modern technology and accuracy and real scientific judgment to the planetary studies.
And that was just not very well appreciated at all by the conventional stellar astronomers.
I mean, we weren't alone.
The solar physicists feel, have felt left out from time to time as well.
And I think having the division and having the ability to present talks at the main AAS meetings was very, very important in helping the rest of the community to become at least more aware that
Planetary science was not just somebody holding up a photograph and saying, well, that's ground haze over there on the limb.
And now they understand that if you're going to study the circulation of the Martian atmosphere, you have to really do...
pretty complex models, even though there's no oceans.
It makes it a simpler system, the model.
But you model that, and then you compare with the observations, and you have the spacecraft going there.
But it's all done by, it isn't just pictures anymore, but it's real good science that's being done.
And I think that's appreciated much more now than it was.
And I think the formation of the division
by giving them a strong point to stand on and help the assimilation or the understanding of planetary astronomy and the assimilation of planetary astronomy into the general overall astronomy picture.
Well, you've just about answered my next question, is do you think that planetary astronomer has a higher standing now among real quote unquote astronomers than it did
when you got your PhD?
Oh, yeah, absolutely.
No question about it.
And it's partly due to the influx of NASA money and the jobs.
But that isn't all.
I mean, at the beginning, I think that the sort of consensus would be that the

and you want to treat this kind of carefully, I think, but I think the consensus was the original people funded by NASA were thought among the community to be those who couldn't get jobs in real astrophysics.
But as we get more and more people coming in from atmospheric physics and geophysics, ended working in planetary astronomy,

they bring their techniques and their kind of rigor that goes on in planetary astronomy now is so much higher than it was even in the very early stages of NASA funding that I think we do have a much higher class of people doing planetary astronomy now than we did before.
And so the easy NASA money, although it fueled a tremendous growth,
also had a negative effect in that you would probably reach further down into the barrel of people than was probably wise in terms of the quality of people that you were funding.
And again, that's a reputation that took a while to dissipate, and I'm not sure it's completely dissipated yet.
Well, now, in addition to having their own sub-society, planetary astronomers got their own journal, Icarus.
And so you don't see planetary papers in the astrophysical journal or astronomical journal.
Of course, other people made the comment that there never were very many in there anyway.
But do you think that the fountain that, let's face it, Carl Sagan made Icarus.
He didn't found it, but he really turned it into something better than what it was.
Do you think that's been good for planetary astronomy?
Or astronomy in general?
Yes and no.
I mean, I think journals like Solar Physics did a major disservice to the solar community.
I think the case is less clear in Icarus, because the solar papers would have been published in the Apche under Helmut, for sure, although they might not have been under Chandra.
And I think having them split off, they agree, was a major problem and a disaster.
And they're trying to come back more into the AAS journals now.
In the case of planetary astronomy, I'm not so sure that that's the case.
I think that having Icarus and building up its reputation to be a journal that
people are, in fact, proud to publish in has been good for planetary astronomy.
And I don't think the case is as clear cut that it was damaging to planetary astronomy, because I do think that the planetary papers would not have been published in A.J.
It's certainly not in Astrophysical Journal.
And again, A.G.U.
would have published some of them, but

I think having Icarus has been an important outlet for the planetary papers, and it's run by the planetary astronomers themselves, the editors of Planetary Astronomer, and the kinds of topics that are of importance, the editorial judgment on these topics is much better than it could have been in either the AJ or the APJ.
In your opinion, is planetary astronomy real astronomy?
Of course.
I mean, astronomy is science, and planetary astronomy is real science.
There's a curious parallel between planetary astronomy and radio astronomy in that in the 40s and 50s, and even into the early 60s, they were considered pariahs, not really respectable.
And as you may recall, most of the early radio astronomy stuff was published in Proceedings of the Institute of Radio Engineers, where my first published paper was, too.
And along with that goes the fact that planetary studies were never looked down on by radio astronomers.
Why do you think this is?
Well, because planets are one of the brightest radio sources and one of the

planet there I mean the radio astronomers started building instruments the first thing they did was look at the planets and of course that's a new area nobody's ever looked at him in the radio region before and so it was it was real science real physics and they they applied a lot of rigor to the to this planetary study and so they helped I think to build the
understanding among planetary astronomers that they had to be a lot more rigorous than they traditionally had been before.
When you were at NSF, this was at a time when NASA was doing the lion's share of funding for planetary astronomy in this country.
Was NSF giving out any money for planetary work?
Oh, yes.
Yeah, they did.
Ground-based radio astronomy, planetary astronomy was done.
at NSF, there were some asteroid studies, I think.
Those were under Harold Lane's direction.
And he's still around, I think, as far as I know.
Might be an interesting person to talk to.
How did you people split the pie with NASA?
Did you meet together or send notes and say, we're going to fund this?
Or didn't you talk at all with NASA?
Oh, well, we just tried to shove as many proposals over to NASA as we could, saying that they had a bigger program and they were better able to judge the worth of the proposal.
It was an understanding.
We used to meet at least once a year with the program directors, and certainly we all knew each other and call each other on the phone and talk about, well, I got a proposal here.
What are you funding in this program?
But
planetary astronomy was being supported at the rate of $30 million a year at NASA and $1 million at NSF.
What can I say?
On a different point of view, I guess this is about six questions in one.
But what I want to ask you is, what do you think the public thinks about astronomy and astronomy?
And then in particular, what do they think about planetary astronomy and astronomers?
And then what should they think?
This is your opinion now.
Well, I think that the public loves astronomy.
I think the public doesn't think there's any difference between planetary astronomy and stellar astronomy.
They look at it all as being the study of the universe, which I think is the way it should be looked at.
As to what
So I think they're equally fascinated by the concepts of black holes and Big Bang and the seeing to the edge of the universe and the fact that we have galaxies of 10 to the 11th suns and so on.
Although as we heard today, maybe it's 10 to the 10th suns and 90% more unseen matter.
But they think these concepts are fascinating.

But they also just love the idea of exploring other planets and sending spacecraft there and looking at the pictures that come back and understanding storms on Jupiter and dust storms on Mars and going out to the depths of Pluto, I mean, Uranus, and finding rings on the planets and so on.
I think this is a fascinating story.
Every aspect of it is fascinating to the public.
What should they think of astronomy and astronomers?
I think they should be fascinated by it.
It's a fascinating field, and it's the age-old question, you know, where did we actually come from?
It's why religion was invented, or at least part of the reason why religion was invented, to explain the creation.
And astronomy is...
pushing back the boundaries where we step from where we know beyond to where we don't know and where we speculate and where we have to make it part of faith or what have you.

Even given this public interest, have astronomers in general in this country and planetary astronomers in particular, you think they've done a good job selling themselves to the public and the Congress?
No, they haven't.
We've been riding on sort of the Cold War.
Everybody must be telling you this.
We've been riding on the Cold War fear of Russia and the importance of having a space program, the importance of going to the moon and Mars first and raising the American flag.
And all of this has helped us to develop
or I developed the funding for astronomy as part of this other great job that we have to do for the country.
And that's all changed.
What do you think was the effect, if any,
I guess maybe I should just, I left that sort of quickly.

What's happened I think is that astronomers have sort of mined this mother load of fear of the Russians and excitement with knowing the universe and the money has just sort of come without them having to really pay back much.

and that's not going to work anymore, and I think we have not done an appropriately good job of having the Congress and the public understand really what astronomy is all about, what astronomers can do, what kind of things we've done that are useful to the nation and have been adapted and used elsewhere, and the importance of just having basic research, curiosity-driven research funded

because you never know when you're going to stumble on something that you can't explain, like in the early 1900s, early part of the century, the calculation that the sun could not possibly support itself except by the gravitational energy released by its contraction, and then it would burn itself up in a few hundred thousand years, which was incompatible with geological record.
And that great conundrum led to...
really pushed the development of understanding the atomic structure of the atom and the atomic energy.
And do we really know that the black holes that we see and the engines in the centers of quasars are driven by
by gravitational energy.
We're going back to the same old source, but maybe, maybe, just maybe it's new physics.
You never know when something like that is going to be absolutely crucial, will be discovered because somebody is curious about a mystery and turns into be one of the most practical

uh developments the important developments that we've had in our civilization this brings up a practical point uh decades now ground-based and probe of exploration of the solar system no trace of life ever existed anywhere except on earth what what kind of negative effect do you think that had on planetary astronomy funding and interest but astronomy in general
I don't think it's had much of an impact on astronomy funding yet anyway.
On planetary astronomy, it probably...
I don't think it's had a major impact.
The failure to discover life forms on Mars.
I think what's more exciting to the people is not whether something else is out there of a low life form
I think what's more exciting is, in fact, the ability of man to perhaps live there, mankind to live there and colonize it.
I think that's a very powerful attraction for the public.
What do you think killed planetary astronomy in the early part of this century?
I don't know.
I don't know enough about what went on.

I've heard stories from Jerry Crone of pages of observing notebooks being excised with a razor blade at Lake Observatory because, I forget who it was, somebody's drawing showed changes on Mars that the person, the director didn't think was appropriate to have made public.
In other words, he thought that the person was seeing things in the middle of the night that weren't there.
What do you think is the state of astronomy right now?
Good, bad, or indifferent?
It's fabulous right now, and the prognosis for the future is looking very grim just because of the change in the funding paradigm that we see facing us right now.
And it's not grim to the point that we will get back to a level of funding that we had in the 1950s, but...
We've had unprecedented growth for the last two decades.
I mean, over the last decade, the Astronomical Society has grown by 40%.
The funding, NASA funding, has grown by a factor of four over that decade.
NSF funding has been decreasing slowly since 1984.
But overall, we've had
a decade of almost unprecedented growth.
And I think what's going to happen is that will just kind of tail off and stabilize.
The problem is that what we're trying to do now is that the way astronomy developed, it needs photons.
In order to get photons, you need large collecting area, and you have to use every photon you get efficiently.
So we had this growth of...
sort of three to four meter size telescopes in, I guess, 1960s, then in the early 70s.
And then in the 1980s, what we've done is develop our ability to use the photons better.
The instrumentation has been our focus.
Well, if you're going to build a big telescope with a large collecting area, you're talking about a lot of bucks.
If you're building more efficient instruments, that can be done a lot more cheaper.
So a lot of our advances and ability to work on this kind of thing has been done rather cheaply in the 1980s with the development of array detectors for infrared, CCD detectors, which are
up to a hundred times more efficient than photographic plates for the visible region.
Moving to new spectral regions, going out into space and riding on the coattails of the space program.
Well now, those kinds of things
advantages are all gone.
In space, the missions are being charged to astronomy, so that the full costs have to be borne essentially by the science.
And the ground, you've run out of improvements that you can make in the instrumentation.
So in order to make further improvements and stretch farther back toward the beginning of time,
you have to go bigger telescopes.
And you're talking about big bucks.
And so astronomy has come to a point where they have to spend big bucks now, just at a time where we geared up to do it.
And we've spent some of them, as in the Hubble telescope.
But now the continuation of the back to X-ray and infrared and the ground-based telescopes
is requiring the expenditure of large amounts of money.

And that's a difficult impasse we're at right now, to need these large projects to make further progress just at a time when the growth of astronomy is tailing off and probably going to decrease a little bit.
Well, it's exactly a similar situation that prevails in planetary astronomy with probes.
Well, I say this.
I'm including the space missions.
infrared and x-ray, but the same thing is true with the, you know, we're not going to get major Galileo missions anymore.
But those are the kinds of missions that we really need to do the job right.

A lot of people have been making a lot of, getting a lot of publicity, and I guess getting money to do research on topics of great practical importance to Joe Blow in the street, and I'm talking about things like watching out for killer asteroids in comets, search for extraterrestrial intelligence, studies of the ozone hole and everything.
Well, this is all reasonable science, but do you think that that's kind of pushing it a little bit too much, or what?
Or is it just get all the money you can doing whatever you want to do?
Well, some of them are very important, like the ozone hole.
We really have to understand, I mean, that's a long-term project that we have to start collecting data on as soon as we can.
I think the amount of money spent on that is excessive, probably, because Congress saw that as something that should be solved.
And so you solve things with money, and they don't understand...
that it takes long and persistent effort to make progress.
Same way with the war on cancer.
They threw a lot of money at it because they were going to solve it, but they haven't made that much progress because the money was not wisely spent.
And I am afraid that we might be in that same kind of thing with the ozone.
But in terms of the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, I think there's a rationale for doing that right now if we really want to know
and that is the tremendous growth in the use of the radio spectrum by terrestrial uses and services.
If we don't search the microwave spectrum now, it'll essentially be blanked out because of all the local interference we're developing.
So that's an important thing to do right now if we're going to make a really coherent search.
We've never had a...
